title: Cichorium
text:
Cichorium is a <a href="genus">genus</a> of plants in the <a href="Cichorieae">dandelion tribe</a> within the <a href="Asteraceae">sunflower family</a>. The genus includes two cultivated species commonly known as chicory or endive, plus several wild species.
Common <a href="chicory">chicory</a> ("Cichorium intybus") is a bushy <a href="perennial%20plant">perennial</a> <a href="herb">herb</a> with blue or lavender (or, rarely, white or pink) <a href="flower">flower</a>s. It grows as a wild plant on roadsides in its native Europe, and in North America, where it has become naturalized. It is grown for its leaves, when it is known as leaf chicory, endive, <a href="radicchio">radicchio</a>, Belgian endive, French endive, or witloof. Other varieties are grown for their roots, which are used as a <a href="coffee%20substitute">coffee substitute</a>, similar to <a href="dandelion%20coffee">dandelion coffee</a>.
True <a href="endive">endive</a> ("Cichorium endivia") is a species grown and used as a <a href="salad">salad</a> <a href="leaf%20vegetable">green</a>. It has a slightly bitter taste. Curly endive and the broad-leafed escarole are true endives.
"Cichorium" is used as a food plant by the <a href="larva">larva</a>e of some <a href="Lepidoptera">Lepidoptera</a> species including <a href="setaceous%20Hebrew%20character">setaceous Hebrew character</a>, <a href="turnip%20moth">turnip moth</a>, and the <a href="grass%20moth">grass moth</a> "<a href="Diasemia%20reticularis">Diasemia reticularis</a>".
Formerly included are several species now considered better suited to other genera: "<a href="Aposeris">Aposeris</a>", "<a href="Arnoseris">Arnoseris</a>", "<a href="Geigeria">Geigeria</a>", "<a href="Rhagadiolus">Rhagadiolus</a>" and "<a href="Tolpis">Tolpis</a>".
